oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "The Airman's Escape"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Airman's Escape" is George W. Puryear's autobiographical account of his capture and escape from a German POW camp during World War I. His account appeared in the April 1919 (p. 452-462) and May 1919 (p. 615-628) issues of Atlantic Monthly magazine. The pages were removed from the magazine and bound together into a booklet. The story is also reprinted (verbatim) as Appendix B in Harold Buckley's book "Squadron 95" (New York: Arno Press, 1972).

After completing pilot training at Issoudun and gunnery school at Cazaux, Puryear served a few months as a ferry pilot before being joining the 95th Aero Squadron on July 16, 1918. He was taken prisoner on July 26 and, after spending time in several POW camps, arrived at Villingen, Germany on September 15. Mass escape attempt made from camp on October 6. On October 11, Puryear swam across Rhine River at Waldshut, Germany to reach Switzerland, becoming first American officer in World War I to successfully escape from a German POW camp.
